post_title: Mahbod Moghadam, who rose to fame as the co-founder of Genius, has died
title: Mahbod Moghadam: Co-founder of Genius & Everipedia Passes Away at 41
post_content:
Mahbod Moghadam, a Co-founder of Genius and Everipedia, Passes Away

Mahbod Moghadam, the colorful co-founder of Genius and Everipedia, as well as an angel investor, passed away last month at the age of 41 due to complications from a recurring brain tumor. The news of his demise surfaced this past weekend, with numerous tributes pouring in on social media platforms, including from former TechCrunch writer-turned-investor Josh Constine.

Moghadam was residing in Los Angeles, working on various projects, one of which was HellaDoge, a short-lived social media platform that rewarded users in dogecoin for contributing dogecoin-related content. His interest in creators' rights and payment methods can be traced back to 2009, following his graduation from Yale and Stanford Law School. After being let go from his first law firm during the economic downturn, he used the severance package to co-found Rap Genius with two of his Yale friends, Ilan Zechory and Tom Lehman.

Rap Genius, later rebranded as Genius, allowed users to annotate and explain hip-hop lyrics, evolving into a platform where rappers could explain their own lyrics. By 2013, Genius had secured funding from Andreessen Horowitz and expanded its remit beyond hip-hop. However, Moghadam's tenure at Genius was marred by controversial behavior, leading to his resignation in 2014.

Following his departure from Genius, Moghadam co-founded Everipedia, which later became IQ.wiki. During his time at Mucker Capital, he expressed regret that Genius contributors were not compensated for their work on the platform. Despite not reaching the same professional heights as during the early days of Genius, Moghadam remained a beloved figure among Genius's most dedicated fans.

Mahbod Moghadam's Contributions and Regrets

Mahbod Moghadam was an intriguing and sometimes contentious figure in the startup world. After co-founding Rap Genius, which later became Genius, Moghadam attracted attention for his outlandish

post_title: US nuclear industry upbeat on small reactors, despite setback
title: US, Canada, Europe: Advancing SMRs as Carbon-Free Power
post_content:
Title: The Future of Small Modular Reactors: A Carbon-Free Power Source

Introduction

The phase-out of nuclear plants in several countries has raised concerns about the future of nuclear power. However, small modular reactor (SMR) manufacturers are optimistic that they can sway skeptical customers with the benefits of carbon-free energy. Despite the cancellation of a next-generation US nuclear plant, there is hope that new SMR projects will become operational by the end of the decade. This article explores the potential of SMRs as a viable carbon-free power source, focusing on recent developments and industry insights.

The Cancellation of NuScale's SMR Project

Late last year, NuScale, a US energy company, announced it was abandoning its small modular reactor (SMR) project in Idaho due to escalating costs. Initially estimated at $5.3 billion, the project's price tag skyrocketed to $9.3 billion, leading to its termination. While this setback may seem disheartening, analysts and industry experts believe that there are positive developments for US nuclear prospects.

SMR Projects in the United States and Canada

GE Hitachi's BWRX-300 SMR design is set to begin producing power in Darlington, Ontario, Canada, in 2029, pending regulatory approval. Construction work is expected to commence in 2025, with the Tennessee Valley Authority also investing in the BWRX-300. Despite the cancellation of NuScale's project, industry experts emphasize that it was a single instance, and improvements in risk sharing are necessary before the industry can build SMRs with repeatability.

Addressing Cost Pressures and Standardization

Some of the reasons for rising costs in nuclear projects are not exclusive to the industry. Higher prices for steel and other commodities, as well as increased uranium prices, contribute to the overall cost. Companies like TerraPower, which is partnering with GE Hitachi, are focusing on innovative "molten chloride" technology, aiming to operate at higher temperatures and improve efficiency. The US nuclear industry recognizes the need to standardize across multiple projects to lower costs.

SMR Developments in the United States and Europe

The United States is currently ahead of Europe in SMR development. Ultra Safe
meta_desc: Discover the potential of Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) as a carbon-free power source. Despite setbacks, like NuScale's project cancellation, the US nuclear industry remains optimistic. With recent SMR projects underway in North America and Europe, these compact nuclear power plants could significantly contribute to global carbon-free energy goals. Standardization, improved risk sharing, and innovative designs are key to addressing cost pressures and ensuring successful SMR implementation. Explore the future of carbon-free energy with SMRs. post_title: A scalable reinforcement learning-based framework to facilitate the teleoperation of humanoid robots
title: Title: Teleoperating Humanoid Robots in Real-Time with Reinforcement Learning
post_content:
Title: Teleoperating Humanoid Robots in Real-Time: A Giant Leap in Robotics

Introduction

The concept of teleoperation, or remotely controlling robots, has opened up a plethora of possibilities for humans to execute various tasks, ranging from the mundane to the complex and even hazardous. Researchers from Carnegie Mellon University have recently unveiled an innovative approach, Human2HumanOid (H 2 O), enabling the effective real-time teleoperation of human-sized humanoid robots using just an RGB camera. This development brings us one step closer to integrating human cognitive skills with humanoid capabilities, which could revolutionize several industries.

H 2 O: A Scalable Solution

The H 2 O method is a significant departure from previous teleoperation techniques, primarily relying on an RGB camera instead of multiple sensors. This simplified hardware requirement allows for easier scaling and widespread use. The primary objective of this research is to create an accessible and user-friendly teleoperation interface for humanoid robots, enabling the collection of vast datasets of human motions for algorithm development and refining human-robot interactions.

Functionality and Components

The H 2 O teleoperation framework is based on reinforcement learning (RL), facilitating real-time whole-body teleoperation of humanoid robots using a single RGB camera. It comprises several components:

1. Retargeting human motions to humanoid capabilities: A novel 'sim-to-data' methodology ensures the feasibility of motions for the humanoid's physical constraints.
2. RL-based motion imitator: This component is trained in simulation using the refined motion dataset and subsequently transferred to the real robot without further adjustments.
3. Reinforcement learning-based model: This model learns new teleoperation policies, enabling the robot to perform a wide array of dynamic whole-body motions in real time.
4. Human motion data cleaning: A crucial step in ensuring the successful replication of motions in robots.

Advantages and Applications

Despite its minimal hardware requirements, H 2 O allows robots to perform a wide range of dynamic whole-body motions in real time. The potential applications for this technology are vast, from household chores and maintenance tasks to medical assistance and human rescue in dangerous locations
meta_desc:
Meta Description:
"Experience real-time humanoid teleoperation with Human2HumanOid! Control human-sized robots using an RGB camera for dynamic whole-body motions. A game-changer in robotics. H2O Teleoperation"

post_title: What we've learned from the women behind the AI revolution
title: Women in AI: Insights from Trailblazers in the Field
post_content:
Title: Women in AI: A Closer Look at the Trailblazers in Artificial Intelligence

Introduction:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a rapidly growing field, attracting significant investment and attention from various sectors. However, the conversation around AI often tends to focus on male figures, overshadowing the contributions of women in the industry. To address this imbalance, TechCrunch's Dominic-Madori Davis and Kyle Wiggers embarked on a series of interviews, discussing the experiences, work, and insights of women in AI. In this blog post, we'll summarize their conversations and provide a fresh take on the topic, ensuring a lively and engaging reading experience for our audience.

Body:

An Intriguing Discovery: Women in AI

The world of AI has been predominantly associated with male figures, leading to an imbalance in the representation of talent and perspectives. To challenge this status quo, TechCrunch's Dominic-Madori Davis and Kyle Wiggers initiated a series of interviews, focusing on women who have made significant strides in the AI field.

Interview Highlights:

Some of the remarkable women they interviewed include:

1. Irene Solaiman, head of global policy at Hugging Face:
Irene Solaiman shed light on her role as the policy head at Hugging Face and her experiences navigating the AI landscape. She emphasized the importance of responsible AI development and deployment, focusing on ethics, fairness, and transparency.

2. Sarah Kreps, professor of government at Cornell:
Sarah Kreps, a seasoned academic, discussed her research on AI and its implications for national security, international relations, and public policy. Her insights on the potential misuse of AI technologies and the need for robust regulations resonated with the audience.

3. Heidy Khlaaf, safety engineering director at Trail of Bits:
Heidy Khlaaf shared her experiences as a safety engineering director at Trail of Bits, where she focuses on ensuring the security and reliability of AI systems. Her expertise in identifying vulnerabilities and mitigating risks has been instrumental in advancing the field.

Engaging and Creative Language for a Blog Audience:

The AI boom is more than just a trend; it's a revolution that brings both opportunities and challenges. Imagine a world where AI

post_title: X makes Grok chatbot available to premium subscribers
title: xAI's Grok Chatbot Now Accessible to More Users on Social Network X's Premium Tier
post_content:
Title: Exciting News: xAI's Grok Chatbot Now Accessible to More Users on Social Network X

Introduction:

In a move to enhance user experience and rival competing chatbots, social network X has announced that it's rolling out access to xAI's Grok chatbot to Premium tier subscribers. This decision follows Elon Musk's announcement last month to expand the availability of Grok to more paid users. Let's delve into the details of this exciting update.

Main Content:

Previously, the Grok chatbot was exclusively available to Premium+ users, who paid a monthly fee of $16 or an annual subscription fee of $168. With the recent update, users subscribing to the $8-per-month Premium tier can now interact with the chatbot in select regions. Grok offers two modes for users: Regular mode and Fun mode. As with other Large Language Model (LLM) products, Grok includes labels that indicate when the chatbot might return inaccurate answers.

Earlier this week, social network X introduced a new explore view within Grok, allowing the chatbot to summarize trending news stories. This feature positions Grok as a direct competitor to similar products like OpenAI's ChatGPT, Google's Gemini, and Anthropic's Claude. Musk has been openly critical of OpenAI's operations in recent months, even going so far as to sue the company in March over what he perceives as a betrayal of its non-profit goal.

Despite open-sourcing Grok last month, xAI has yet to provide details about the training data used for the model. My colleague Devin Coldewey questions whether this is the latest version of the model and if the company will be more transparent about its development approach and training data information.

Grok's Capabilities and Controversies:

Grok not only summarizes news stories but also generates headlines, as seen in a recent example where the chatbot wrote a fake headline stating, "Iran Strikes Tel Aviv with Heavy Missiles." This incident raises questions about the chatbot's accuracy and potential for misinformation.

Musk's Motivations:

Musk's decision to expand access to Grok might be driven by his desire

post_title: Spotify launches personalized AI playlists that you can build using prompts
title: Spotify's AI Playlists: Personalized Music with Prompts
post_content:
Spotify's AI Playlists: A New Era of Music Personalization

Spotify, the popular music streaming platform, is diving headfirst into artificial intelligence with its new AI Playlists feature. This innovative tool allows users to create custom playlists based on written prompts, providing an unprecedented level of personalization. The feature is currently in beta and will be available on Android and iOS devices in the U.K. and Australia, with plans for further expansion and refinement in the coming months.

post_title: Working from home isn't going away, even if some CEOs wish it would
title: Remote Work vs. In-Office: Post-Pandemic Shift, Boosting Productivity & Talent Pool
post_content:
THE FUTURE OF WORK: REMOTE VS. IN-OFFICE – A Deep Dive

The traditional office setup is undergoing a seismic shift as remote work becomes increasingly popular. In the late 1980s, working from home was a rarity, but today, it has become a sought-after norm for many. According to recent data, 14% of U.S. workers currently work from home full-time, a number that is expected to rise to 20% by 2023. Moreover, 58% of white-collar employees desire flexibility in their work schedules, allowing them to work from home a few days a week.

Nevertheless, the post-pandemic landscape has been fraught with mixed messages regarding the return to the office. Some companies, such as IBM and Amazon, have been pushing hard to get employees back to the office, while others, like Wayfair, have concentrated on remote workers in layoffs. Despite this, many CEOs, including Amazon's Andy Jassy and Tesla's Elon Musk, have expressed reservations about remote work, citing concerns about productivity and the need for in-person collaboration.

However, recent research from the University of Pittsburgh Katz School of Business found that return-to-office mandates did not improve firm performance. In fact, such mandates negatively affected employee satisfaction. Furthermore, studies have shown that employees value flexibility over location, suggesting that remote work can lead to higher levels of engagement and productivity.

Karen Mangia, president and chief strategy officer at the Engineered Innovation Group, believes that flexibility is the key to employee satisfaction and productivity. "Employees who have some degree of flexibility over where and when they work are reporting higher levels of employee engagement and productivity," she said. Moreover, companies that force employees to return to the office may face issues related to employee burnout.

Remote work also offers companies access to a more diverse and extensive talent pool than is possible with a traditional in-office setup. Dion Hinchcliffe, an analyst at Constellation Research, noted that companies opening up their hiring to remote workers were finding better candidates than before.

The debate now centers on how much time, if any, employees should spend in the office. Some tech companies are leaving this decision up to their employees, with positive results. Git
meta_desc: Discover the benefits of remote work as it becomes increasingly popular – boost productivity, attract top talent, and enhance flexibility. Embrace the future of work today! RemoteWork FutureOfWork Productivity TalentAcquisition Flexibility.
focuskeywords:
LABOR MARKET TRENDS: REMOTE WORK BOOM

The labor market is witnessing a significant shift as remote work becomes increasingly popular. According to recent data, 14% of U.S. workers currently work from home full-time, a number that is projected to rise to 20% by 2023. Moreover, 58% of white-collar employees desire flexibility in their work schedules, allowing them to work from home a few days a week.

The post-pandemic landscape has been marked by mixed messages regarding the return to the office. Some companies have pushed for employees to return to the office, while others have focused on remote workers in layoffs. However, recent studies have shown that remote work can lead to higher levels of engagement and productivity, and that employees value flexibility over location.

Karen Mangia, president and chief strategy officer at the Engineered Innovation Group, emphasizes the importance of flexibility in the workplace. "Employees who have some degree of flexibility over where and when they work are reporting higher levels of employee engagement and productivity," she said.

Remote work also offers companies access to a more diverse and extensive talent pool than is possible with a traditional in-office setup. Dion Hinchcliffe, an analyst at Constellation Research, noted that companies opening up their hiring to remote workers were finding better candidates than before.

The debate now centers on how much time, if any, employees should spend in the office. Some tech companies are leaving this decision up to their employees, with positive results. GitLab, for instance, is a fully remote company with over 1,300 employees in 67 countries. The company has reported higher productivity and lower turnover rates compared to traditional in-office setups.

In conclusion, the trend towards remote work is likely to continue, offering benefits for both employees and employers. Companies that prioritize flexibility and remote work options may have a competitive advantage in attracting and retaining top talent.

post_title: When it comes to building startups in Boston, success begets success
title: "Boston's Thriving Startup Ecosystem: Hubspot Success & Factors Fueling Growth"
post_content:
Building Successful Startups in Boston: The Factors Fueling Its Thriving Ecosystem

Boston has become a thriving hub for startups, with successful exits such as Hubspot and Klaviyo. The city's supportive ecosystem fosters innovation and growth, making it an attractive destination for aspiring entrepreneurs. In this blog-friendly format, we will discuss the key factors contributing to Boston's startup success and highlight the unique aspects of its ecosystem.

The Success Story of Hubspot and Beyond

In 2004, Hubspot founders Brian Halligan and Dharmesh Shah, then MIT graduate students, developed the concept of inbound marketing. Their idea evolved into a successful company, which went public in 2014 with a market cap of over $30 billion. Boston's supportive environment, including top-tier universities, experienced investors, and access to capital, played a significant role in Hubspot's success.

Boston's startup ecosystem has produced other successful companies, including iRobot, Wayfair, Acquia, and Carbon Black. In 2022, Klaviyo joined the list of successful Boston-based startups with its public offering. This continuous cycle of success generates wealth for founders, creating an angel funding system for new generations of entrepreneurs.

The Building Blocks of a Successful Ecosystem

1. Robust University System: Boston is home to 35 colleges and universities, with an additional 9 institutions in the broader metropolitan area, including Harvard, MIT, and Tufts. These institutions serve as breeding grounds for new ideas and a constant flow of talented STEM students.

2. Access to Capital: Despite its smaller size, Boston ranks fourth nationally in Q4 2023 for total venture investment, with $3.5 billion invested in 208 deals. The city's strong investor base and supportive environment contribute to its ability to attract and retain talent.

3. Talent Pool: Boston's universities produce a steady stream of skilled graduates, providing a strong foundation for startups. This talent pool is particularly rich in AI and machine learning, making it an ideal location for enterprise and cybersecurity investments.

4. Research and Development: Boston's thriving R&D sector, combined with its tech talent, creates a unique environment for startups to
meta_desc: Thrive: Discover the Key Factors Driving Boston's Startup Success. Explore successful stories like Hubspot & Klaviyo, a strong university system, access to capital, a talented workforce & a thriving R&D sector in this SEO-optimized meta description! BostonStartups Entrepreneurship

post_title: Price of zero-day exploits rises as companies harden products against hackers
title:
Start of Generated Content: [Zero-Day Exploits: Millions Offered, Finding Them Gets Harder](https://example.com/news/zero-day-exploits-prices-rise-hacking-difficulty)

The Soaring Price of Zero-Day Exploits: A Hacker's Challenge
In the world of cybersecurity, the value of zero-day exploits has reached new heights. These elusive vulnerabilities, unknown to software manufacturers, can provide unauthorized access to iPhones, Android devices, WhatsApp, iMessage, and popular browsers like Chrome and Safari. A startup called Crowdfense is now offering millions of dollars for these tools, reflecting the increased difficulty in hacking products as they become more secure.

Crowdfense recently published its updated price list for zero-day exploits. The company is now offering between $5 and $7 million for zero-days targeting iPhones, up to $5 million for Android phones, and up to $3.5 million for Chrome and Safari zero-days. WhatsApp and iMessage zero-days are valued at $3 to $5 million.

The escalating prices for zero-days can be attributed to the growing efforts of tech giants like Apple, Google, and Microsoft to fortify their devices and apps against hackers. Threat intelligence teams play a crucial role in discovering zero-day vulnerabilities and ensuring they are addressed. In 2023, Google reported that hackers used 97 zero-day vulnerabilities in the wild, with 75% targeting Google products and Android devices.

End of Generated Content
post_content:
Title: The Soaring Price of Zero-Day Exploits: A Hacker's Challenge

In the world of cybersecurity, the value of zero-day exploits has reached new heights. These elusive vulnerabilities, unknown to software manufacturers, can provide unauthorized access to iPhones, Android devices, WhatsApp, iMessage, and popular browsers like Chrome and Safari. A startup called Crowdfense is now offering millions of dollars for these tools, reflecting the increased difficulty in hacking products as they become more secure.

An Update on Zero-Day Prices

Crowdfense recently published its updated price list for zero-day exploits. The company is now offering between $5 and $7 million for zero-days targeting iPhones, up to $5 million for Android phones, and up to $3.5 million for Chrome and Safari zero-days. WhatsApp and iMessage zero-days are valued at $3 to $5 million. In its 2019 price list, the highest payouts Crowdfense offered were $3 million for Android and iOS zero-days.

The Rising Difficulty of Finding Zero-Days

The escalating prices for zero-days can be attributed to the growing efforts of tech giants like Apple, Google, and Microsoft to fortify their devices and apps against hackers. Dustin Childs, the head of threat awareness at Trend Micro ZDI, stated, "It should be harder year over year to exploit whatever software we're using, whatever devices we're using." Shane Huntley, the head of Google's Threat Analysis Group, echoed this sentiment, stating that the time and effort required from attackers have increased, resulting in higher costs.

The Role of Threat Intelligence Teams

Threat intelligence teams, such as Google's, play a crucial role in discovering zero-day vulnerabilities and ensuring they are addressed. In 2023, Google reported that hackers used 97 zero-day vulnerabilities in the wild, with 75% targeting Google products and Android devices. Spyware vendors, which often collaborate with zero-day brokers, were responsible for the majority of these attacks.

The Future of Zero-Day Exploits

As vendors continue to implement stronger security measures, the process of exploiting vulnerabilities

post_title: Magnets are switching up the keyboard game
title: Magnetic Switches Revolutionize Mechanical Keyboards: Hall Effect & Customizable Actuation Points
post_content:
The Future of Mechanical Keyboards: Magnetic Switches

Mechanical keyboards have experienced a surge in popularity, evolving from a niche product to a mainstream staple in home offices during the pandemic. Brands like Akko, Drop, Ducky, Epomaker, and Keychron have become household names, offering a multitude of layouts and customizable components. However, as high-end features have become commonplace in budget keyboards, the market has become somewhat stagnant. Enter magnetic switches, a promising innovation set to revolutionize the mechanical keyboard scene.

What sets magnetic switches apart is their ability to quickly change the actuation point, or the point during the keypress where the switch registers your downstroke. Traditional mechanical switches rely on a physical connection to close an electrical circuit, while magnetic switches utilize magnets and springs, activating by sensing changes in the magnetic field. This technology, popularized by Dutch keyboard startup Wooting, has the potential to transform the way we interact with mechanical keyboards.

The Hall Effect

Magnetic switches operate using the Hall Effect, a principle discovered in the 19th century. When a magnetic field is applied to a current-carrying conductor, a voltage proportional to the magnetic field is produced perpendicular to the current flow. In magnetic switches, a permanent magnet is placed in the stem, and as the key is pressed, the sensor on the keyboard's PCB detects the change in the magnetic field. This change allows for a more precise and adaptable actuation point.

Customizable Actuation Points

One of the most significant advantages of magnetic switches is the ability to customize the actuation point. For gamers, a lower actuation point can provide a competitive edge, allowing for faster response times. For typists, a higher actuation point can prevent accidental keypresses and improve typing accuracy. This adjustment can be made through simple key combinations on the keyboard or through manufacturer-provided software tools.

Furthermore, magnetic switches enable the customization of release points, which can be beneficial for gamers looking to quickly spam keys or create unique macros. With this high degree of customization, users can experiment with their favorite settings without having to physically change switches.

Drawbacks and Limitations

post_title: Canoo reveals it paid for CEO's jet, AT&T leaks records and X announces NSFW plans
title: Microsoft, Quantinuum Achieve Quantum Breakthrough; Apple Shifts Focus to Home Robotics
post_content:
Welcome to this week’s tech roundup, where we delve into the most exciting and thought-provoking stories that shaped the world of technology. Let’s dive in!

Y Combinator’s Demo Days: A Recap

The tech ecosystem eagerly awaited Y Combinator’s Demo Days, and our venture desk team covered the event with a discerning eye. Our day one and day two reports, along with an AI roundup and analysis pieces, provide insights into the latest innovations and emerging trends.

Microsoft and Quantinuum Achieve Quantum Breakthrough

Microsoft and quantum computing startup Quantinuum announced a scientific breakthrough in quantum computing. The companies successfully ran thousands of experiments on a quantum computer without a single error, a milestone that has long evaded the industry. This achievement could pave the way for more accurate and powerful quantum computers in the future.

Apple’s Home Robot Project

Fresh off canceling its autonomous EV project, Apple has shifted its focus to home robotics. According to reports, the company has assigned Apple Home and AI executives to work on a robotics project for households. Although details remain sparse, this development could signal Apple’s entry into the smart home market with a new physical product.

Noteworthy News

Canoo’s Financial Woes: Canoo, the EV startup, paid $1.7 million in 2023 for its CEO’s private jet rental, which is double the amount of revenue the company generated that year.

AT&T Data Leak: AT&T has reset millions of account passcodes after a massive data leak containing customer records was made public earlier this month.

OpenAI’s Accessible ChatGPT: OpenAI now allows everyone to access its flagship conversational AI, ChatGPT, without requiring an account. However, the user experience will differ for non-account holders.

Microsoft Unbundles Office 365: Microsoft introduced new versions of its Microsoft 365 and Office 365 subscription services, excluding Teams, its business collaboration chat offering, due to EU regulatory scrutiny and complaints from rival Slack.

Ghost Autonomy Shut Down: Ghost Autonomy, a startup working on autonomous driving software for automaker partners, has closed its doors after raising nearly $220 million
